awd_titl_txt: Preparing Highly Qualified Women STEM Majors to Become Successful Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
Studies show that there is a significant positive relationship between the presence of minority teachers in primary and secondary schools, and minority student performance. This issue is critically important to California schools, which enroll about 72% minority students but only employ about 29% minority teachers. Mount Saint Mary's University (MSMU) Noyce program will address the need for highly qualified teachers in the STEM disciplines, decrease the minority and female gender gap, and ultimately increase underrepresented groups participation in STEM. The goal of the program is to enable low-income, high-achieving, first generation women from underrepresented groups who have a passion for STEM to pursue teaching careers in middle and secondary high-need schools in Southern California. This program will recruit, prepare and support 17 women majoring in mathematics, biochemistry, biological sciences, or chemistry, who will concurrently pursue a teaching credential. 

MSMU is implementing the project in collaboration with the Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD) and other high-need schools in the Los Angeles area.  Project activities include intensive on- and off-campus recruitment as well as program modifications and add-ons, such as Noyce program orientation, STEM-based internships with the campus Math Lab and the California Science Center, a supportive cohort environment, continuing faculty mentoring and quarterly meetings, mini-grants to enhance scholars' classroom resources, and a new course that combines mathematics, pedagogy and California Subject Examinations for Teachers (CSET) preparation. A unique aspect of the program will be training that will provide the pre-service teacher with a certificate in inclusive and responsive teaching (CIRT), which will prepare them to provide successful learning experiences for students in high need schools. The project will contribute to the body of knowledge by providing a model of effective practices in recruiting, retaining, and preparing a population that is especially absent in STEM education -- women from minority and low-income backgrounds. The project's activities and strategies for fostering greater interest in teaching mathematics and science among these students will be tracked and evaluated. Particular attention will be paid to strategies for attracting high-achieving women who have not previously considered a career in teaching. The evaluation of the project will carefully track the impact of each program component on the students' teaching practice, satisfaction and persistence in the profession.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce) invites proposals that address the critical need for recruiting, preparing, and retaining highly effective elementary and secondary mathematics and science teachers in high-need school districts.

The NSF Noyce grant was awarded to Mount Saint Mary's University's (MSMU) in 2016. The goal of the program was to enable low-income, high-achieving, first-generation women from underrepresented groups who have a passion for STEM to pursue teaching careers in high-need middle and high schools in Southern California. MSMU recruited students (for this report, Scholars) from its BS Biochemistry, BA Biological Sciences, BS Biological Sciences, BA Chemistry, BS Chemistry, and BA Mathematics programs into its Secondary Education Teaching Credential Program and provided them with the support necessary to become classroom-ready middle or high school math or science teachers in high-need schools.

Six Scholars were recruited, against a goal of 17. Three of these majored in mathematics, one in biology, one in biochemistry, and one in biology and child development. Of the six Scholars recruited, four self-identify as Latina, one as Black/African-American, and one as Asian/non-Hispanic and Black/African-American, indicative of our commitment to reducing gender and ethnicity gaps in the STEM teacher workforce. 

We saw positive impact with regard to providing Scholars with support to enable them to persist and complete the program and become credentialed. The successes of those Scholars who have become credentialed, or are well on their way to become credentialed, are a combination of the hard work of the Scholars themselves, and the commitment of program leadership to providing ongoing personal support and engagement, which was reflected in feedback from Scholars. Throughout the program, Scholars were provided with opportunities to explore the field of teaching through participation in quarterly meetings, one-on-one academic counseling, research projects and internships, and early teaching experiences in MSMU's Learning Resource Center and in area schools.

Feedback from a Scholar led to a revised track at MSMU for Biology students, in which program-required education classes can be taken during freshman and sophomore year (meaning for the Noyce program that students would still become eligible to become Scholars in their junior year, but could begin taking education courses earlier). Engaging potential future teachers as freshman and sophomore students and enabling them to take an education class during their early years is now pursued as another means of introducing them to the possibility of teaching, in addition to making the concurrent degree and credential more feasible. The intent for the Noyce program was to solve Scholars' challenge of bridging both education and STEM requirements, removing conflicts for lab time; it was also intended to respond to concerns regarding extended enrollment to become credentialed. Graduate education courses were already cross-listed with undergraduate so that undergraduate students could take them; the revisions described here have also made it possible for undergraduate education students to take graduate education courses offered in the summer, which previously were not cross-listed with undergraduate courses. These revisions were implemented for the 2019-2020 academic year and remain in place.

A graduated Scholar now teaching a high-need school continues to contact MSMU's Noyce program leadership directly to help fulfill her school's teacher recruitment needs, most recently for a physics teacher and for a student teacher in chemistry.

Noyce program information was shared with another NSF grant program at MSMU recently concluded, "Supporting Scholars to Succeed in STEM," known as S4 (Track 1 of the NSF S-STEM program, award #1564677), which had the participation of STEM and education faculty members who also contributed their experience to the Noyce Scholarship Program. The S4 program benefitted from collaboration with the Noyce program, and MSMU was recently approved for a six-year grant for Track 2 of the NSF S-STEM program, award #2221112, for our project titled "Expanding STEM Scholar Support Systems," known as S4X.

Our Noyce program's focus on preparing teachers to work in high needs schools inspired our expanded efforts toward implementing dedicated anti-racist teaching practices. This resulted a three-year transformation grant from the Branch Alliance for Educator Diversity, scheduled to conclude in May 2023. The insights and practices from our experience as a Noyce grantee also enabled us to partner with a Los Angeles Unified School District charter school in a Teacher Residency Capacity Grant from the state of California to collaboratively design and develop an equity-based, learner-centered, sustainable teacher residency program. This program supports the retention of teachers of color already employed at the charter school, and the retention and growth of Teaching Partners (paraprofessionals) of color to become credentialed. Both programs described above were directly inspired by MSMU's experiences as a Noyce grantee and contribute to the creation of a new generation of diverse female teachers serving as effective educators and role models for diverse low-income students in high need schools in under-resourced communities.
